title-group.article-title: An Equivocal Negritude: Léon–Gontran Damas's Lyric Masterpiece,Black-Label(1956)

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Damas was long considered one of the three leading Negritude writers, along with Césaire and Senghor, but in recent years he has been increasingly, unjustifiably overlooked. His lyric masterpiece, the long poemBlack-Label, has never been thoroughly analyzed. After contrasting Damas's poetic vision to that of his peers, this article explains and illustrates his striking originality and esthetic complexity in using verbal repetitions—notably anaphora, local framing, and pervasive refrains—to depict the collective emotional trauma of the black diaspora, slavery, and racial prejudice. Damas's subtle modulation of anguish and sarcasm explains why Henry Louis Gates's and Anthony Appiah's authoritativeAfricanaencyclopedia credits him with having elaborated the most telling and universal representation of “the rising international black consciousness after World War II.” The personal psychodrama of a ceaseless struggle against abjection alternates with a firm refusal to forget or forgive historical injustices, current persecutions by white racists, and the economic exploitation inherent in capitalist globalization.

Critics who hypostatize the text consider the critical concept of “authorship” as controversial or, worse yet, naïve and old-fashioned. I claim that fiction and its components are verbal artifacts, and that the “implied author” effect inBlack-Labelis potentiated by anaphora, equivocation, various forms of framing, and verbal repetitions within the text, and can be inferred from these features. For a complementary example, from feminist criticism, see Porter ,“Le modernisme sentimental.”As with any elements of a text, readers' interpretations will vary. See Thomasson , and also Walsh . A modified verbal echo that introduces each of two successive paragraphs functions as a discourse marker signaling a variation on a theme. The text ofBlack-Labelassociates this device with creativity, contrasting it both with the complex framing in part IV, which asserts ostensibly spontaneous communication, and with the simple framing associated withl'incommunicabilité(the impossibility of communication) in part II. In each instance, the content is associated with emotion and discovery. Some examples of the paragraph-initial verbal echo with slight variations are “Une peine immense … La peine immense” ‘An immense sorrow … The immense sorrow’ (11); “Et pourquoi … Pourquoi” ‘And why … Why’ (25); “Le bel enfant de choeur” ‘The handsome choirboy’ (38); “… ELYDÉ deux êtres confondus en un seul” ‘Elydé two beings blended into one’ (44–45); “Soudain ce soir surgis … ce soir soudain surgis” ‘Suddenly having appeared this evening … this evening having suddenly appeared’ (59); “tu me parlas de toi” ‘you told me about yourself’ (60–61).
